En el tiempo libre le gusta escuchar música.
texts.en:
Luis is 33 years old and lives with his parents in the Chillanes settlement, within the Bolivar province.  He is part of the Unión Central Parroquia San José del Tambo community and he farms and raises animals.   The community is located an hour from the co-op.  Luis raises cacao.

He is asking for a loan to clean his fields and have a better production.

He makes his purchases in the city of Mata de Cacao.

His dream is to have a business.

His challenge is a lack of working capital.

He likes to listen to music in his spare time.

loans.use: to clean his fields.

loans.name: Theresa's Group

texts.en:
Theresa’s group has five members and is located in the Greater Accra region. The names of other members are Ofori, Samuel, Mavis and Sophia. They trade in fruits, shoes, coconuts, soap and bags. 

Theresa is 35 years old, single and has no children. She sells fruits (pineapples, pawpaw, grapes, bananas, etc). Theresa is pictured with the two men and two women of her group. She has ordered GHS 2,000 wealth of fruits from the market so that she can serve her customers better. She has been doing this business for 10 years. 

Theresa joined ID-Ghana in 2010 and has graduated since then. She is in her seventh loan cycle with ID-Ghana now. She would like to increase her capital base, that is why she and the other members are requesting a total amount of GHS 6,300. This will also bring more profits so that she can continue her building project.

loans.use: to buy more fruits (pineapples, pawpaw, grapes, banana, etc) to sell to customers.

loans.name: Reah

texts.en: Reah is engaged in farming, running a hotel and selling clothes. She plans to use the loan to buy a water tank, which she will use to collect water during the rainy season. The project will take two weeks to complete and will benefit seven family members and many neighbors. Reah faces a lack of sufficient water to drink. This is her sixth loan with SMEP DTM, and the previous loans she has repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a water tank for use by her family and neighbors

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is a 30-year-old gentleman, married to a housewife, and the father of four children (six, four, two and six months)  He is a farmer in Narok town, and has been farming for the past seven years, making a monthly income of KES. 50,000. 

He learned about KADET LTD from other farmers in his neighborhood who are already registered and are being funded by KADET LTD. 

Samson has acquired his first loan of KES. 30,000 which will enable him to acquire farm materials including fertilizers and sprays.  He will use the proceeds to meet the family's basic needs.

His dream is to grow his farming business to a large commercial venture.

loans.use: to acquire farm materials such as fertilizer and sprays.

loans.name: Norma Lisandra

texts.es: Doña Norma de 31 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos, se dedica a la venta de dulces de conserva de coco desde hace 10 años con las ganancias que obtiene logra cubrir algunos de los gastos de su hogar, Doña Norma desea hacerle una mejora a su hogar pero no tiene capital suficiente para poder realizarlo por eso  solicita un credito para poder comprar materiales para construir un cuarto que necesita en su hogar y asi podra su familia vivir mas comodos.
texts.en:
Doña Norma is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children. She has been selling sweets, such as coconut preserves, for 10 years. With the income she earns, she is able to pay for some of the household expenses.

Doña Norma wants to make an improvement to her home, but she does not have sufficient capital to proceed. For this reason, she is requesting a loan in order to buy materials for building a room she needs in her home. This will allow her family to live more comfortably.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for building a room.

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
Delia tiene 30 años, esta casada con Reynaldo . Vive en una casa alquilada junto a sus dos menores hijos siendo ellos su gran motivo de esfuerzo y trabajo.Posee un puesto en el mercado de abastos de su localidad.
Desde hace 7 años se inicio solo con la venta de pollos logrando ocupar un puesto en el mercado de su localidad pero hoy gracias a la confianza brindada y el trabajo que desempeña puede ofrecer a su distinguida clientela una variedad de víveres tales como Verduras, enlatados y el infaltable producto de alto consumo en su localidad como es el pollo.Siendo este su tercer préstamo otorgado por parte de Kiva muestra su agradecimiento por ser un gran apoyo y aliento para trabajar con fluidez esperando mantener el lazo de confianza.En esta nueva ocasión desea contar con 1,000 nuevos soles e invertirlos en la compra de mercadería para abastecer nuevamente su negocio con la compra de sacos de arroz, verduras y demás comestibles así como reservar dinero para la compra de pollo a las avícolas locales.
texts.en:
Delia is 30 years old and married to Reynaldo.  She lives in a rented home along with her two young children who are her main reason for her work and effort.  She has a stall in the local market.

She began selling chickens seven years ago in a local market stall, but thanks to her confidence, she is now able to offer her customers a variety of food such as vegetables, canned goods, and the high consumption product in her area, chicken.  Being that this is her third Kiva loan, she shows her gratitude for the great support by her great desire to work and keep the trust.  On this occasion she is asking for a loan of 1,000 PEN so she can buy merchandise to stock her business once again, with sacks of rice, vegetables, and other foods and also to save money to buy chicken from local farmers.

loans.use: to stock her store.

loans.name: Safiatu

texts.en:
Safiatu is 48 years old and lives in West Point, one of the most populated and well-known market areas in Montserrado county. She is married and has five children aged between 10 and 28 years. Only two of her children are in school and live at home. For the past eight years she has been selling food items, like palm oil, rice, and pepper, to customers. One problem she faces in her business is rainy seasons.

She is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase food items to resell, like palm oil, rice, and pepper. She likes her business because of the way people respond to it. Safiatu's plan for the future is to buy a piece of land and build a house.

loans.use: to purchase food items to resell, like palm oil, rice, and pepper

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman and has been blessed with three, school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanamisi is coming to Yehu Microfinance for her first loan, in the amount of KES 15,000. She will use the loan to start a meat goat business. With the loan she wants to purchase goats, for rearing and reselling at a price to butcher operators. She dreams of expanding her business and earning more profits in the future.

loans.use: to start a new business, by purchasing goats for rearing and reselling to butcher operators

loans.name: Finda

texts.en: Finda is 31 years old and lives in West Point, which is located in Montserrado County. She was unable to attend school. She is a married woman with four children ages 6, 10, 13, and 19. She sells iron market goods (door lock, hinges, door-catcher etc) at the market place in West Point. She started her business by selling the same goods for her oldest sister and later opened her own table in her community. She has being doing this business for the past five years and is not facing any problem now. She is asking for a loan to increase her inventory (door locks, hinges, door-catcher, etc). Her dream is to become a big businesswoman and build her own house.

loans.use: to increase her inventory (door locks, hinges, door-catcher etc).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La clienta vive en Guayaquil. Empezó  vendiendo comida como arroz con menestra y carne a sus  amistades más cercanas, actualmente alquila un local y es hay donde vende sus platos como arroz con menestra y carne, pollo, chuleta. Trabaja desde las 14h00 hasta las 22h00.

Su dificultad es que en ocasiones su enfermedad no la deja cocinar ya que es pvvs (persona viviendo con vih sida). No es casada, tiene un hijo de 12 años el cual estudia en escuela fiscal.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar productos de carnes, vegetales para sus prestamos. Su sueño es tener una casa propia disfrutar junto a su hija, casarse tener un local estable y sobre todo tener salud.
texts.en:
This borrower lives in Guayaquil. She started selling food, such as vegetable stew with rice and meat, to her closest friends. She currently rents a space where she serves dishes such as vegetable stew with rice and meat, chicken, and chops. She works from 2:00 P.M. to 10:00 P.M.

The borrower faces difficulty on occasion when her illness does not allow her to cook. She is a person living with HIV/AIDS. She is not married and has a 12-year-old child who is studying at a state school.

With this loan, the borrower will buy products, such as meat and vegetables, for preparing her offerings. Her dream is to have a house of her own where she can enjoy being with her daughter. She would also like to be in a stable location and, most of all, remain healthy.

loans.use: to buy meat and vegetables.

loans.name: Jose Adan

texts.es:
José, solicita un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de seguir invirtiendo en la agricultura de granos básicos; esta inversión le permitirá comprar materiales  agrícolas para realizar el cultivo tales como: abono, plaguicidas, insecticidas, herbicidas y pago de mano de obra.
El crédito anterior le ayudo a aumentar la productividad y las utilidades las invierte en  los gastos del hogar y familiares; las condiciones económicas se han optimizado y las circunstancias familiares se mantienen y se encuentran bien de salud.
texts.en:
Jose is asking for a new loan so that he can buy basic grains.  This investment will allow him to buy farming supplies such as compost, insecticides, and herbicides for his crops and pay for labor.

The previous loan helped him increase production and he is able to invest the proceeds into the home and family.  Financial conditions have improved and the family is doing well and is healthy.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies and pay for labor.

loans.name: Guwa Kushinga Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 61-year-old Arthur from Masvingo. He is married and has six children.  Arthur runs a retail business and sells groceries and clothes. The business has been in operation for 12 years. He says the main challenge faced is the transportation of goods from the wholesaler. Arthur has requested a loan of $1,200 to buy groceries and clothes for resale. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will boost his business resulting in increased profitability and quality of life. In the future Arthur plans to open a second shop in town.

loans.use: to buy groceries for resale

loans.name: Blessed Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 29-year-old Vimbai from Masvingo. She is single with no children. She cares for four dependents. Vimbai runs a retail business and sells groceries, wheelbarrows, shovels and plows. The business has been in operation for six years. She says the main challenge she faces in her business is the high cost of transporting goods from town to the market. Vimbai has requested a loan of $1,200 to buy groceries and building material for sale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will increase her income resulting in improved family welfare. In the future, Vimbai plans to own a shop in town.

loans.use: to buy groceries and hardware

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Mwembeni Group

texts.en:
Merina, who is in her early 30s, is a married woman with three children, a girl and two boys, who are in school. For a period of three years now, she has been running two businesses: a cosmetics business and a broiler. She is doing fine in this field and in her family. She works from 8am to 9pm daily and is able to make a good profit per month.

This will be her 15th loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. With the previous loans, all of which she repaid back successfully, she managed to open her current cosmetics shop and increase her broiler activities. With the profit received, she bought a plot of land where she expect to build a house in the future. She will use this loan to restock the cosmetics in her shop. She dreams of building a house.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Mwembeni," which totals 13 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock the cosmetics in her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Tsunga Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 52-year-old Nyaziwe from Masvingo. She is widowed with two children. She also cares for two dependents. Nyaziwe runs a retail business selling clothes, blankets and jackets. The business has been in operation for 18 years. She says the main challenge faced is transport as there is a scarcity of transport in her area. Nyaziwe has requested a loan of $150 to buy clothes and jackets for sale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will go towards the upkeep of her family. In the future, Nyaziwe plans to open a boutique in town.

loans.use: to buy jackets and other clothes to sell

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
Alejandrina nació en la comunidad de Cotañi y vive en la misma comunidad donde nació. (La comunidad de Cotañi está localizada en el distrito de Huancarani dentro de la provincia de Paucartambo del departamento del Cusco, Perú). Ella tiene 33 años de edad, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos. 

Alejandrina es una mujer emprendedora y trabajadora que se dedica a la artesanía, ella tiene un pequeño taller en su domicilio donde elabora tejidos como por ejemplo chompas, chalinas y otras cosas más pero también se dedica a la fabricación de telares.   
 
Un grupo de vecinas le invitaron a participar del banco comunal “Intipakareq” porque es una persona responsable y amable. En esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar materiales de trabajo como lana de alpaca y oveja. Agradece a todas las personas por el préstamo pues se compromete a pagar puntual sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Alejandrina was born in the community of Cotañi and still lives there. The community of Cotañi is located in the District of Huancarani in Paucartambo Province, Department of Cusco, Peru.

Alejandrina is 33 years old, married, and has four children. She is an enterprising and hardworking woman who makes handicrafts. Alejandrina has a small workshop in her home where she makes knitted items such as sweaters, scarves, and other items. She also makes woven items with the use of a loom.

A group of neighbors invited her to participate in the “Intipakareq” Communal Bank because she is a responsible and cheerful person. Alejandrina is taking this opportunity to request a loan so that she can buy materials for her work, such as alpaca and sheep’s wool. She thanks everyone for this loan and promises to be punctual with her payments.

loans.use: to buy materials, such as alpaca and sheep's wool.

loans.name: Jean Damscene

texts.en: Jean Damscene is a 29-year-old man from Gicumbi District in the Northern Province of Rwanda. He is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. Jean Damscene started selling lights in December 2012 and he has sold 20 lights to date, providing clean energy to 100 people. With the money he makes from selling and recharging lights, he will pay for the school fees of his two children (Denise and Aline).

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Guni

texts.en:
Guni is a married man and blessed with five children who all attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

Over the years, he has operated a meat goat selling business, selling at the market to town dwellers and butcher shop operators. He faces a challenge of the high cost of transportation in his business. He dreams of expanding his business and expanding in the near future.

With the KSHS 50,000, he wants to purchase goats for resale. He joined Yehu because of favorable loaning policies.

loans.use: to purchase goats to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Murambiwagroup

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 33-year-old Chinosiya from Masvingo. He is married with three children, one attending school. Chinosiya runs a retail business selling clothes, shoes and jackets. The business has been in operation for four years. He says the main challenge he faces is high competition in the market. 

Chinosiya has requested a loan of $250 to buy jackets and clothes. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow him to increase his disposable income. In the future, Chinosiya plans to open a shop in town.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a 46-year-old man from Gicumbi District in the Northern Province of Rwanda. He is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. 

Emmanuel started selling lights in December 2012, and he has sold 20 lights to date, providing clean energy to 100 people. With the money he makes from selling and recharging lights, he will pay for the school fees of his six children (Callixte, Vedaste, Frederic, Beather, Isaac and Eric) and purchase a cow.

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La clienta vive en Guayaquil. Empezó recorriendo en un triciclo por el Cristo del consuelo vendiendo articulos de hogar, despues poco a poco le gusta las ventas le da gracias a Dios ya que con eso se mantiene. Trabaja sola de 9h00 a 18h00.

Su dificultad es que en ocasiones recae en su salud y se queda reposando ya que ella es pvvs (persona viviendo con vih sida). Otras de de las dificultades son los cientes que piden a crédito por los productos y no pagan.

No es casada, ni tienen hijos. Con el préstamo quiere comprar artículos como ropa, ollas, cucharas, ventiladores. Su sueño es tener un local comercial disfrutar junto a su familia y darles trabajo a personas que estén en las mismas condiciones que ella.
texts.en:
This borrower lives in Guayaquil. She started out traveling by tricycle through Cristo del Consuelo, selling household goods. Gradually over time, she began enjoying making sales. Thanks to God, she has been able to support herself. The borrower works alone from 9:00 A.M. to 6:00 P.M.

She faces difficulty on occasion with her health when she goes into relapse. This requires her to take a rest. The borrower is a person who is living with HIV/AIDS. Her other difficulties include customers who request credit for their products and don’t pay.

The borrower is not married and has no children. She will use her loan to buy goods such as clothing, cookware, spoons, and fans. Her dreams include having a retail shop, enjoying moments with her family, and providing jobs to other people who are in the same condition as her.

loans.use: to buy clothing, cookware, spoons, and fans.

loans.name: Mose

texts.en:
Mose is a widowed mother and has been blessed with seven children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past two years, she has operated a vegetable kiosk, selling green vegetables, tomatoes and potatoes. She sells primarily to local neighbors. Mose dreams of expanding and establishing a shop in the future.
With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes.

loans.name: Victory Group

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 35-year-old Farai from Masvingo. He is married with one child. Farai runs a retail business selling blankets, shirts and dresses. The business has been in operation for 5 years. He says the main challenge faced is high competition in the market. Farai has requested a loan of $250 to buy blankets and clothes for sale. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will increase his household income resulting in a better quality of life. In the future, Farai plans to open a flea market table in town.

loans.use: to buy blankets and clothes.

loans.name: Rasoo

texts.en:
Rasoo is a married woman and has been blessed with one child who is still too young for school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.
For the past four years, she has operated a retail shop, selling household consumables to local customers. She faces a major challenge with the high cost of transportation to her place of operation.
With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans, maize flour and soft drinks. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans, maize flour and soft drinks.

loans.name: Drocella

texts.en:
Drocella business was boosted by the Kiva funding she received. Her business has grown and she is making more money from recharging the lights.
She is seeking a top-up loan of $50 to purchase 10 more rechargeable LED lights, which she will resell to people without electricity in her village. Every week or so, these customers will return to her to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. She started selling lights in December 2012 and he has sold 30 lights to date, providing clean energy to 150 people. She is also a farmer and will reinvest the money she makes into expanding her other business to earn more money for herself, her husband Isidole, and their 3 children.

loans.use: to pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Kumba

texts.en:
Kumba is 38 years old and lives in the town of West Point, one of the most populated and well known markets in Montserrado County. She is single with five children ages 13, 16, 18, 20 and 21, only two of them are in school. The oldest ones are out of school.
For 10 years Kumba has been selling red oil, pepper, rice, etc. at the local market. Sometimes she does not have enough money to buy more inventory. She enjoys talking with her customers, and learned how to trade from her auntie a long time ago.
Kumba has requested a loan to buy more inventory (red oil, pepper, rice etc.). In the future, she would like to have her own house.

loans.use: to buy more inventory (red oil, pepper, rice etc).

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is 30 years old and blessed with four children aged eight, six, four and two years old. He is a livestock trader in Narok and has been running the business for the past four years making a monthly income of KES. 20,000.
He learnt about KADET LTD from the market place where KADET LTD was carrying out a marketing activity.
He has borrowed his first loan of KES. 30,000 from KADET LTD which he intends to use to purchase more livestock.
The anticipated profit will be reinvested to boost his business. His future dream is to improve his living standards.

loans.use: to buy livestock.

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en: Jeannette is 28 years old. She is married with three children and they all go to school. With the loan, Jeannette will buy more cooking oil, rice, and sugar for sale. The profits will be used to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Theophile

texts.en: Theophile is a 35-year-old man from Rulindo District in the Northern Province of Rwanda. He is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. Theophile started selling lights in November 2012 and he has sold 20 lights to date, providing clean energy to 100 people. He is also a shopkeeper and will reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business to earn more money for himself, his wife Angelique and their children.

loans.use: to pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married lady who is 51 years old and blessed with five children aged between 28 and 16 years old. She makes clothing for men, women and children in Kapsabet and has been in operation for 28 years earning an income of KES. 15,000.
She has borrowed her fifth loan of KES. 60,000 from KADET LTD and wishes to use this amount to pay school fees for her child who is in university and also buy fabric. The profits she earns from her business will be used to purchase more textile materials for her business and also repay the loan.
Her dream is help her children get the best education and also prosper in her business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child and also buy fabric for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Monique

texts.en: Monique is 27 years old. She is married to a businessman. She sells construction materials. With the loan, she wants to buy more cement and iron sheets. The profits from the business will be used to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more cement and iron sheets.

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en: Donatha is 39 years old. She is married with seven children. She sells various items in a boutique. With the loan, she wants to buy more rice, sugar, and cooking oil. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more rice, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a widow who is 60 years old. She is blessed with five children aged 25, 23, 21, 20, 19 and 16 years old. She operates a boutique in Narok and has been running the business for 20 years earning a monthly income of KES. 30,000.
Alice learnt about KADET LTD from other business colleagues who are registered members of KADET LTD. She has borrowed her first loan of KES. 30,000 from KADET LTD which she intends to purchase more clothing for her business.
The anticipated profit will be used to pay school fees for her last born child. Her dream is to improve her living standards and own a residential plot of land.

loans.use: to buy clothing for her boutique.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a 49-year-old lady who is married and a mother of three school going children. She learnt about KADET LTD from her husband’s colleague who is already been funded by KADET.
She operates a phone accessories shop and also has money transfer services, which earns her a monthly income of KES. 40,000. She has acquired her first loan of KES. 100,000 which she will use to buy phone accessories as well as float for the money transfer business.
She plans to use the profits to stock some snacks in her kiosk. Her dream is to open several similar stalls in the town.

loans.use: to buy phone accessories, and float for money transfer services.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent is 26 years old and single. He does motorbike transport and has been in the business for five years. He has requested a loan to buy more spare parts to use on the motorbike. He plans to reinvest the profits back into the business.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts for his motorbike.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past five years, she has operated a firewood and charcoal selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passers-by. Her major challenge in the business is the high cost of transportation.
With this requested loan she wants to diversify into transport and purchase a motorcycle for the business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for the business.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en: Claudine is 29 years old. She is married with five children. She owns a business, selling various items in her boutique. With the loan, she wants to buy more sugar, rice, and salt for sale. The profits from the business will be used to solve her family problems.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, rice and salt for sale.

loans.name: Jezi Konnen Group

texts.fr:
Marieclaude est la coordonatrice de son groupe Jezi Konnen. Elle habite dans la région de CAP-H d’Haïti où de l’électricité est rare et de l’eau est très limitée. Elle a dirigé son commerce de vente divers ellel est aussi pendent les 9 dernières années. Elle est marie et elle a 2 enfants. 

Marieclaude voudrait utiliser cet emprunt pour investir dans achete produits divers, que des vêtements, des cosmétiques, des chaussures. Des autres membres des Jezi Konen ont besoin d’un emprunt pour tels commerces comme vendre des produits alimentaires et des produits cosmétiques. Marieclause dit que son rêve est d’agrandir son commerce pour qu’il devenir un grand commerçant.
texts.en:
Marieclaude is the coordinator of Jezi Konnen Group. She lives in CAP-H region in Haiti, where electricity is scarce and water is very limited.

For nine years, she's been running a business selling various products. She's married and has two children.

She would like to use this loan to buy various products, such as clothing, cosmetics, shoes… Other members of Jezi Konnen Group need a loan to buy food products and cosmetics to resell.

Marieclaude says that her dream is to expand her business in order to become a big merchant.

loans.use: to buy clothing, cosmetics, shoes, etc

loans.name: Pialo

texts.fr: Pialo est une jeune âgé de 27ans. Mariée, elle est  maman de 02 enfants dont 01 sur les bancs de l’école. Ils sont âgés de 06 et 03ans. Elle revend des produits de détails (savons, biscuits et de l’eau).  Son premier crédit sollicité à WAGES lui servira d’acheter des marchandises pour répondre à la demande des clients. Elle espère devenir grossiste et aider ses enfants à s’épanouir.
texts.en:
Pialo, age 27, is married and the mother of two children, age 6 and 3. One of them goes to school. She retails various products (soaps, biscuits, and water).

This first loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, will be used to buy products to meet customer demand. She hopes to become a wholesaler and help her children blossom.

loans.use: to buy soaps, biscuits, and water

loans.name: Elisa

texts.pt:
Casada e mãe de 2 filhos que frequentam a Escola, vive na casa própria e não sustenta mais ninguém.
É docente e com o presente empréstimo pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, chapas, e outros) para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa. 
No futuro deseja concluir a casa e casar oficialmente, para tal compromete-se a pagar devidamente o empréstimo para solicitar mais a Hluvuku. 
O desafio é economizar mais o seu salário e fazer mais empréstimos.
texts.en:
Elisa is married and the mother of 2 children who go to School. She lives in a house she owns and doesn't support anyone else.

She's a teacher and with this loan she plans to buy construction material (cement, sand, metal sheets and others) to continue the building work on her house.

In future Elisa hopes to finish her house and officially get married. To this end, she commits to duly paying off the loan so as to solicit further loans from Hluvuku.

Her challenge is to save up her salary and ask for more loans.

loans.use: buy construction material (cement, sand, metal sheets and others) to continue the building work on her house.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.pt:
Solteira e mãe de 1 filha que frequenta a Escola, vive na casa própria e sustenta mais uma sobrinha que vive com ela.
É docente e com o presente empréstimo pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, azulejos, sanitas, lavatórios, e outros) para fazer acabamentos na obra da sua casa. 
No futuro deseja concluir a casa e mobilar, para tal compromete-se a pagar devidamente o empréstimo para solicitar mais a Hluvuku. 
O desafio é economizar mais o seu salário e iniciar um negocio para aumentar a renda.
texts.en:
Cristina is single and the mother of 1 daughter who goes to School. She lives in a house she owns and supports a niece who lives with her.

She's a teacher and with this loan she plans to buy construction material (cement, tiles, toilets, sinks and others) to finish building her house.

In future Cristina hopes to finish her home and furnish it. To this end, she commits to duly paying off the loan so as to solicit further loans from Hluvuku.

Her challenge is to save up her salary and start a business to increase her income.

loans.use: buy construction material (cement, tiles, toilets, sinks and others) to finish building her house.

loans.name: La Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El grupo "La Nueva Esperanza" esta integrado por 13 personas entre hombres y mujeres muy trabajadores pero sobretodo muy entusiastas, se encuentran ubicados en la cabecera del municipio lugar que se caracteriza por sus fiestas tradicionales. Los integrnates del grupo platican que anteriormente estaban trabajando con otra microfinaciera su nombre era "La Conchita", sin embargo, tenian muchos problemas internos fue como decidieron cambiar de microfinanciera  y conocieron a Vision Fund, para ellos era una nueva forma de trabajo, "iniciar nuevamente", entonces fue como decidieron ponerle "La Nueva Esperanza". Doña Mary es la representante del grupo tiene 48 años de edad es una señora casada con el señor Manuel con quien ha formado una familia con cuatro hijos que aun dependen de dicha pareja. 
La señora Mary se dedica a la venta de tacos desde hace 16 años, ella cuenta que inicio porque un familiar de su esposo tenia un restaurante-bar pero tiempo despues dejo su negocio fue asi como el esposo de Doña Mary retomo el negocio de la venta de los tacos. Esta vez la señora Mary  solicita el credito para comprar refrescos, gas, bancos y sillas para su negocio. Doña Mary le gusta su negocio, con esfuerzo y mucho trabajo han podido lograr hacerse de cuatro puestos de tacos ambulantes, sin embargo, los lugares no son propios solo son prestados y Doña Mary vive con la angustia de que algun dia le lleguen los desalojen de sus lugares. Doña Mary comento "Solo que con esta situacion sueño con tener mi propio negocio en mi casa donde ya no vivamos angustiados" asi como la señora Mary tiene metas las demas integrantes del grupo tambien tienen sueños y metas con sus familias pero lo que mas les importa es mejorar la calidad de vida. Los integrantes del grupo son Teodora, Cristina, quienes tambien invertiran en su taqueria, J Carmen invertira en su vulcanizadora, Juan Luis invertira en cafe internet, Jose Juan, Francisco invertiran para maiz para tortillas, Isabel invertira en colchas y sabanas, Pascuala invertira en productos de fantasia, Imelda invertira en zapatos, Arnulfo invertira en su negocio de dulces, Elena abastecera su tienda de abarrotes y Jaqueline invertira en su papeleria. Todos los integrantes estan muy contentos y agradecidos con Vision Fund y KIVA por el credito otorgado para sus negocios sera de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
The communal bank "La Nueva Esperanza" is comprised of 13 men and women who are hard workers and, especially, enthusiastic.  They are located in the main municipality which is known for its traditional celebrations.  The members of the group say that they used to work with another micro-finance group named "La Conchita", but they had many internal problems so decided to change.  They met Vision Fund and, for them, it is a new way of working.  Since they were beginning again, they took the name "La Nueva Esperanza" (New Hope).  Mary, 48, is the representative of the group.  She is married to Manuel and they have four dependent children. 

Mary has been in the business of selling tacos since she was 16.  She says she began the business because a relative of her husband's had a restaurant-bar but after a while decided to close it.  Mary's husband opened the business again to sell tacos.  On this occasion, Mary is requesting a loan to buy soft drinks, gas, benches and chairs for her business.  She enjoys her work and through much effort and hard work has been able to open four street vending locations.  However, these are not her own places, but on loan, and Mary lives with the anguish that one day she will be ousted.  Mary says "I only dream about having my own business in my house so we do not have to suffer like this".  

Like Mary, the other members of the group also have their dreams and goals with their families, but what they want the most is to improve their lifestyles.  The members of the group are Teodora and Cristina, who run taco stands, J Carmen who has a tire business, Juan Luis who has an Internet Café, Jose Juan and Francisco who will buy corn for tortillas, Isabel who will buy bedspreads and sheets, Pasucala who will buy costume jewelry, Imelda who will buy shoes, Arnulfo who will invest in his pastry business, Elena who will buy groceries for her store and Jacqueline, who will invest in her stationery store.  All of the members are very happy and grateful to Vision Fund and KIVA for this loan which will be helpful to their businesses.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks, gas, benches and chairs.

loans.name: Bintihamisi

texts.en:
Bintihamisi is married and has two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a fish selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors. She earns her other source of living from her husband who has a business.  

With the KES 40,000 she wants to take out medical insurance coverage for her family members. She decided to join to acquire financial services for her business growth.

loans.use: to take out medical insurance coverage for her family members

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene is 35 years old. She sells beers in the pub that she has been running for 13 years. She has requested the loan to buy beers and sodas for sale. With the profits, she will reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy more beers and sodas for sale.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima has started  operating a food stall business recently, cooking flatbread and beans and selling from home to local neighbors with the help of her previous Kiva loan. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding to a café business. 

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice, maize flour, and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice, maize flour, and sugar.

loans.name: Dennis

texts.en: After leaving his job at an NGO in Uganda, Dennis returned to his village to start a family. Now with a wife and three young children, Dennis is working extremely hard running poultry, printing, and consumer goods businesses. With the help of a Kiva loan, he will be able to purchase more of the energy efficient stoves that have been a major health and fuel-saving product for his customers. Unlike most entrepreneurs, Dennis doesn’t just wait for customers to come to him, he travels to smaller villages and performs demonstrations everywhere from offices to hospitals to small shops. The son of farm laborers, he did not grow up with much money, but his dream is for the extra income generated from stove sales to allow him to send all three of his children through school as well as expand his business to neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase energy efficient stoves to expand his business to neighboring towns

loans.name: Marie Jeanne

texts.en: Marie Jeanne is 44 years old. She sells milk and has been in the business for eighteen years. With the loan, she wants to buy more milk for resale. She is planning to use the profits to make more savings for the better future of her business.

loans.use: To buy more milk for resale.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a 46-year-old woman who lives in the town of West Point, one of the most populated and well known markets in Montserrado County. She lives with her fiancee and three children. Her children live at home with her and attend school. She was unfortunate and could not attend school herself. 

She is involved in the sale of sugar, flour, rice and oil, etc. in the local market. Sometimes buying goes slowly, but most of the time she realizes a profit. She learned this way of trading from her mother a long time ago. She enjoys talking with her customers and the profit she makes. 

She has requested a loan to buy sugar, flour, rice and oil, etc. to increase her sales. In the future, Comfort would like to own a house and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy sugar, flour, rice and oil, etc. to increase her sales.

loans.name: Comfort  S.

texts.en:
Comfort is 33 years old and lives in West Point, one of the most populated and well known markets in Montserrado county. She was unable to attend school but she says she is good at managing her business. She is single and has four children, ages 12, 14, 16 and 19. All of them are in school and live at home.

For the past fifteen years Comfort has been selling  candy, biscuits, soft drinks, oil, sugar and flour, etc. from a small shop in the market. She has lots of customers and makes a good profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more candy, biscuits, soft drinks, oil, sugar and flour, etc. for her business. Comfort hopes to improve her business and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more candy, biscuits, soft drinks, oil, sugar and flour, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.ru: Джамиля позитивная и жизнерадостная женщина. Она живёт со своей семьёй в маленьком посёлке. Ещё с молодости Джамиля мечтала в будущем стать учительницей и работать в школе. Но сразу после окончания школы родители выдали её замуж, поэтому ей пришлось забыть о своей мечте и посвятить своё время домашнему хозяйству. Потом появились дети и появилось много забот. Чтобы иметь какой-то доход, она начала разводить скот, она купила пару коров и стала ухаживать и откармливать их. А молоко, которое давали эти коровы она продавала в своём посёлке. Её дети помогали ей разносить молоко и различные молочные продукты покупателям. И по сей день, вот уже как 15 лет Джамиля занимается этим бизнесом - откормом скота. Её муж поначалу помогал ей в реализации данного бизнеса, но потом он поехал в Россию на заработки, и сейчас ей помогает продолжать данный бизнес её старший сын. В России муж работает водителем такси и каждый месяц присылает ей заработанные деньги, но их хватает только на пропитание. А Джамиля хочет увеличить свой бизнес, и хочет купить больше скота, чтобы получать больше дохода и улучшить экономическое состояние своей семьи и накопить деньги на обучение детей в Университете. Поэтому сейчас Джамиля обратилась в Арванд и хочет получить кредит для покупки скота для расширения своего бизнеса. Она очень надеется на поддержку и заранее благодарит Арванд.
texts.en: Djamilia is a positive and cheerful woman. She lives with her family in a small village. Since she was a little girl, she dreamed of becoming a school teacher. But right after graduating from school, her parents married her off, and she had to forget about her dreams and devote her time to being a housewife. Soon there were children, and with them, lots of worry. In order to have some type of income, she began to raise livestock. She bought a pair of cows and she began to tend to them and fatten them. She sold the milk in her village. Her children helped her to deliver the milk and various dairy products. Now Djamilia has been operating this business of raising and fattening animals for 15 years. Her husband drives a taxi and sends her money each month, but it's only enough for them to buy food. Djamilia wants to expand her business by buying another cow to get more income, improve her family's economic standing, and to save money to send her children to college. So Djamilia has turned to Arvand for a loan to buy a cow to expand her business. She is counting heavily their assistance, and thanks Arvand in adavnce.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Francess S.

texts.en:
Francess S. is a 24-year-old woman who lives with her three children in West Point, one of the most populated and well known markets in Montserrado county. She did not attend school and she is single. Her children's ages are 6, 9 and 11, and they are in school. 

For the past five years she has been selling slippers and teddy bears from a table in the local market. Sometimes business goes slowly, but most of the time she realizes a profit and she uses it to sustain her family. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more slippers and teddy bears to increase her sales. She hopes to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more slippers and teddy bears to increase her sales.

loans.name: Jemah

texts.en:
Jemah lives in West Point, one of the most populated and well known markets in Montserrado county. She is 41 years old. She did not attend school, but she is engaged in business. She is married with six children between the ages of  24 and 12. Two of them are in school and they all live at home. 

For the past twenty years Jemah has been involved in a business. Presently she sells oil, garlic and flours, etc. in the local market. She received a little amount from her mother to establish her business, and she learned this way of trading from her mother. She likes her business because she makes a good profit. 

Jemah is requesting a loan to purchase oil, garlic and flours, etc. to increase her business. Her plan is to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase oil, garlic and flours, etc. to increase her business.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is 33 years old and lives in the West Point community, which is a populated area in Montserrado County. She is single with one child, age 14. Her child is going to school and lives at home. 

Hawa did not go to school but she is a business-minded woman. Over the past four years she has being selling biscuits, candy and sardines, etc. in the local market without facing any serious problems so far. She started this business by selling cola-nut. She sells six days a week, spending 10 hours each day with her business. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more biscuits, candy and sardines, etc. to increase her sales.

loans.use: to purchase more biscuits, candy and sardines, etc. to increase her sales.

loans.name: Kenari

texts.en:
Kenari is a Balinese artisan who specializes in silver jewelry. She has been selling through NOVICA since 2006. She would like to invest in more sterling silver to create new jewelry designs.

 This is her story:

"I come from Celuk, famous for its gold and silversmiths, so I learned to design and craft jewelry from a very young age. In 2003, I married an artist from Gianyar and went to live with his family, like Balinese tradition dictates. However, I obsessed with crafting jewelry and fortunately, my husband understood."

"I am so grateful for the chance to get a micro-credit loan. This will help me to create more stock and also to prepare new designs. I am so thankful for all your support, and hopefully, you would like to collect the jewelry I make. It would also be wonderful if you'd recommend my jewelry to your friends and families. It will mean so much when my designs are known and worn by lovely people everywhere in the world. Thank you so much for your help in making my work sustainable."

Use the link below to view Kenari's silver jewelry on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/5467

loans.use: to invest in more sterling silver to create new jewelry designs.

loans.name: Jonas

texts.en:
Jonas is 34 years old. He lives with his son. He has been selling provisions (milk, Milo, toffee, biscuits, bread, margarine, rice, etc.) for several years. He sells in his community. He is an enterprising, active, responsible and honest man to his customers. 

He wants to make an investment to buy more provisions, but he needs capital. That is why he is asking ID-Ghana for a loan of GHS 2,000 that will allow him to buy milk, Milo, toffee, biscuits, bread, margarine and rice, etc. This way Jonas can get more profit so that he can take good care of his son and get him educated.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell to customers. (milk, Milo, toffee, biscuits, bread, margarine, rice, etc.)

loans.name: La Union Group

texts.en:
Lourdes is the coordinator of her group, La Union (the union). This group consists of 20 micro-entrepreneurs located in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, where Lourdes makes her home in a simple structure with her three children and her long-term partner. She has been working hard to support her children.

Lourdes has sold clothing for around five years, having started the business with her own savings. Now retailing a variety of products, she is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza International with which she will purchase clothes, shoes, cosmetics, etc. Lourdes will reinvest the profits in her enterprise and save some for any family needs that may arise. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, shoes, clothes, etc.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 36 years old and lives in West Point, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is married with three children, ages 5, 19 and 20. All of her kids are going to school. She is a high school graduate, and she is a potential business woman. Her husband is not working. Nevertheless, Alice manages her business well to enable her to support their home. 

Over the past three years she has been running a table in the local market without facing any serious problem. This business started with a little amount of money she got from her mother. She sells six days every week, spending 10 hours a day with her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more fashion slippers for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fashion slippers for her business.

loans.name: Welleh

texts.en:
Welleh is 36 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is single with four children who are in school and live at home. Welleh did not go to school but she is a business-minded woman. 

For the past seven years she has been selling fish in the local market without facing any serious problem so far. She started this business by selling for her mother. She sells six days a week, 10 hours each day. She is requesting a loan to purchase more fish to increase her sales. Her plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to increase her sales.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
As a native of San Antonio, Michael has always been in tune with the local music scene, nightlife and culture of the South Texas city. While working as a webmaster for four years, Michael learned about the powerful impact that online technology and social media have in bringing people together.  His technical experience in graphic and web design, coupled with his love for entertainment, led him to create entForm.com, an online entertainment news portal and e-commerce marketplace.

Rather than compete against or replicate existing local entertainment websites, entForm collaborates with other websites to feature their articles and events on one central website for the convenience of San Antonio residents and visitors alike. After extensively researching the strengths and weaknesses of similar websites, Michael determined that the best way to differentiate entForm was to actively engage its users. In addition to searching articles and events, users will be able to submit their own articles, music and photographs, as well as comment and share information with their social network friends.

The one-stop-shop website will also have an e-commerce component. Users will be able to sell and purchase a variety of items through the site’s online marketplace in a secure and appealing manner. Advertising opportunities will be available to local businesses looking to reach new audiences and grow their own sales.

Michael is excited to launch his new business venture. To augment what he has learned in his four years as a webmaster, Michael has sought opportunities to learn more about managing and operating an online business.  Michael is a member of Geekdom, a collaborative workspace for self-proclaimed geeks in San Antonio. He is also enrolled at Internet Business Mastery Academy where he will receive internet entrepreneur mentorship.

With his loan from Accion Texas Inc., Michael will be able to purchase the equipment and software necessary to execute the first phase of his business plan. Eventually, he hopes to hire additional employees and add new features to the website.

loans.use: to purchase equipment and software to create his website.

loans.name: Celeste

texts.en:
Celeste bakes custom cakes. From cardamom cupcakes with whips of towering frosting to custom-baked Spiderman birthday cakes, from red velvet and chocolate cake pops, to coconut cream wedding cakes, she can bake it. In addition to cakes, pies and cake balls, Celeste bakes vegan cupcakes. 

Her company, Celeste’s Cakes N More, LLC, is a home-based business, but her goods can be purchased at restaurants throughout Houston. 

Celeste’s Cakes produces baked goods for all occasions and caters to individuals and companies. Celeste works for Wal-Mart on a full-time basis, and operates her business on the side. Originally from Houston, Texas, Celeste has informally been operating for the last 20 years, but she formalized her company on September 5, 2012.

Celeste borrowed $5,450 from Accion Texas to purchase equipment and supplies and to advertise. This is her website: http://gateaux.vpweb.com/?prefix=www
Her Facebook page is http://www.facebook.com/pages/Celestes-Cakes-N-More/196326340397637

loans.use: to purchase equipment and supplies and to advertise.

loans.name: Cupertina

texts.en:
Since opening her small restaurant, Topis, more than 12 years ago, Cupertina has been serving delicious traditional Mexican food to new and loyal clients that visit her establishment in Atascosa, Texas.

Cupertina is a hardworking mother, and soon to be grandmother, who has goals to expand the family restaurant. After hearing an interview about micro-lending on Univision, Cupertina came to Accion Texas Inc. for help to fund that goal.  

With the small business loan she received, Cupertina is able to add more tables and seating in her restaurant, as well as complete a few minor renovations to the space. Her hopes are to make the atmosphere even more inviting and accommodating to her diners.

loans.use: to purchase more seats and tables and renovate her restaurant.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Ever since he was 15 years old and offered his father a helping hand with his air conditioning repair business, Juan has known what he has wanted to do. So by the time the 32-year-old started his own business, Superior Refrigeration A/C Service & Supply, Juan had more than a decade of experience. 

“It all started with an idea in high school,” Juan said. 

From helping his father with his AC business, Juan knew that people in South Texas desperately need their air conditioning to function during the summer. Understanding the simple economics of supply and demand, he knew his experience would go a very long way. Juan said his father taught him to do a good job, shake someone’s hand, and complete a job. Since opening his own business 2 ½ years ago, Juan said he has seen a dramatic demand for his services. 

Juan turned to a banker at Capital One, who then referred him to Accion Texas. Juan used his Accion Texas loan to purchase a special service van to carry equipment and also for working capital. With the extra working capital, he is able to purchase the parts he needs to repair air conditioning units in advance.  

Additionally, Juan employees subcontractors for large projects and is also subcontracted by his father’s business when his father needs help. Juan describes his business as a very fast moving and dynamic industry where technology and skill are always in demand. In the future, Juan plans to hire employees to continually grow his business.

loans.use: to purchase a special service van to carry equipment.

loans.name: Anarkan

texts.ru:
Анаркан - лидер группы "Бек Бол", ей 46 лет, воспитывает 2 детей. Анаркан активная женщина, работает продавцом в магазине, а также в качестве дохода для своей семьи занимается животноводством и полеводством, стартовав этот бизнес с суммы (KGS) 5,000 сом. Благодаря упорному труду Анаркан в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний  день имеется  1 дойная корова с приплодом, 10 голов мелкого рогатого скота, земельный надел в 3,0 га с фасолью, картофелем и многолетними травами. 
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Анаркан обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 80,000 сом (KGS)  на покупку скота для получения доходов от продажи молока.  Доходы от кредита Анаркан планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, в ближайшее семья хотела бы приобрести автомобиль.
texts.en:
Anarkan is the leader of the group "Bek Bol". She is 46, and has two children. Anarkan is an active woman; she works as a salesperson in a store, and she also raises livestock and farms. She started the latter business with 5000 soms (KGS). Thanks to her hard work, she now has a one dairy cow with a calf, 10 head of sheep, and 3 hectares of land planted in beans, potatoes, and perennial grasses.

With the goal of expanding her business, Anarkan has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan in the amount of 80,000 soms (KGS) to buy livestock to obtain income from selling milk. Anarkan plans to invest the proceeds obtained from the loan into further enlarging her livestock herd, and in the future, her family would like to get a car.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Idalia

texts.en:
For 30 years, Idalia operated a meat market in her home region of Michoacán, Mexico. When she, her husband and their four children decided to move to Texas, re-opening their business was a simple decision. Los Corrales Meat Market is now open in their new hometown of Mission, Texas.

Idalia says what makes her meat market different from others around Mission and surrounding towns is that they sell beer, spices and other items, along with meat. She also offers four food packages, all of which come with a free bag of charcoal. She says when she first opened her business, it was mainly to provide for her four children. Now her children and her daughter-in-law work with her. 

Idalia’s son met and spoke with an Accion Texas Inc. employee and told his mother about the loan opportunity. Idalia is using her working capital funds to fix the refrigeration unit on the meat cases, as well as to purchase inventory, including meat and charcoal.

Additionally, Idalia hopes to join the world of 21st century advertising by developing a website in the near future. 

Idalia is primarily relying on her children to run the entire operation and they have been doing a successful job so far. She maintains that without her children’s help, it would not be possible. She said she absolutely loves the atmosphere of working alongside her children.

loans.use: to fix the refrigeration unit on the meat cases and purchase inventory, including meat and charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy manure for her banana plantation.

loans.name: Marisela

texts.en:
Marisela has always loved children and enjoyed being able to stay home with her children as they were growing up.  However, when the economy slowed down in 2001, Marisela knew that she would need to start working to help supplement her husband’s income.  

She initially had difficulty finding work that would be flexible enough to allow her to raise her own children until she joined the Chicano Federation Child Care Training Program and became licensed to run a daycare program out of her home.  Running a daycare allowed Marisela to stay home with her children, while enabling her to support her family.

Marisela knows that taking care of children is not just about making sure nothing happens to them, but also about providing an enriching environment for them to play and thrive. She will use her $2,000 Kiva loan to make upgrades to her house and purchase additional toys and furniture for the kids under her care. She also hopes to market her business to fill her program to capacity of eight children.

With the necessary upgrades, Marisela hopes to eventually secure the necessary state license to increase her capacity to 14 children, further increasing her income and allowing her to achieve a more stable future for her family.

loans.use: to make upgrades to her daycare and purchase additional toys and furniture for the kids under her care.

loans.name: Justin

texts.en:
Growing up almost 2,000 miles away from the Pacific Ocean, Justin never imagined he would be running his own business renting scuba and surf gear in the sunny coastal city of San Diego. Most likely destined to be doing hard labor for an oil company back in Louisiana, Justin drove out to California to visit a family friend and drastically changed the course of his future.
 
In what he calls a “fall off the turnip truck” moment, he arrived at the beach and immediately felt a connection. Embraced by the warm climate and laid-back culture, Justin knew he had arrived at his new home. Even though he had been a country boy all his life, Justin’s ambition led him to get his scuba certification. Seeing the potential to quickly generate a return on his investment, he went through the process of becoming a certified scuba instructor and started working for different shops around town. 

He eventually started his own company, Pacific Beach Sports, renting water sports equipment such as scuba gear and paddleboards. He moved into a storefront in the heart of San Diego’s famous Pacific Beach, filled the racks with equipment to rent or buy, and made connections with other instructors to lead certification classes in the space. 
 
Now almost two years in, he has seen significant growth but is ready to take his business to the next level. Justin’s $7,000 Kiva loan will enable him to purchase additional inventory and better market his business to grow its visibility in the community.  

Justin hopes to eventually grow Pacific Beach Sports into San Diego’s premiere water sports rental and sales company, helping others experience the natural beauty and excitement of the city that he fell in love with so many years ago.

For more information or to rent gear on your next trip to San Diego, check out his website: http://www.pacbeachsports.com/

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and better market his business.

loans.name: Benik

texts.en: Benik is 55 years old. He lives with his wife, son and daughter in Varser village, which is in Gegharquniq region. Benik graduated from Yerevan Radio Technical College in the communications field as a technician. Since 1990, Benik has worked as a chief of a seismic station in the Emergency Situations Ministry of Armenia. Benik’s wife engages in farming and animal breeding in Varser village. Benik’s son is working in the Emergency Situations Ministry of Armenia and, at the same time, studies in the Crisis Management State Academy. Benik has applied to Kiva lenders for a loan to pay his son’s tuition fees for this semester.

loans.use: to pay his son’s tuition fees for this semester.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Heghine

texts.en: Heghine is a 27-year-old teacher. She lives with her parents in Tsovagyugh village, which is in the Sevan area. Heghine’s mother engaged in farming, and her father is now in the Russian Federation for Seasonal Works and helps to meet his family’s needs in Armenia. Heghine graduated from the State Pedagogical University of Armenia n the  Department of Education portal. Hegine works in school as a teacher and, at the same time, she studies at the State Pedagogical University of Armenia to receive her master's degree. Heghine needs a loan of 190,000 AMD (Armenian drams) to pay for her education fees.

loans.use: to pay her graduate school tuition fees.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for a greenhouse.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor has been in the freighting industry for almost two decades. Using his savings from years working as a truck driver, Victor went into business for himself almost 15 years ago, starting his company Victor J’s Trucking.  Victor was hesitate at first to take this leap, but he's glad he did.

Victor was referred to Accion Texas Inc. for a loan by A+ Credit Union while he was seeking out the working capital he needed to purchase a trailer with greater storage capacity for his truck. The acquisition of the trailer has allowed Victor to deliver more freight to his clients in fewer trips, increasing the overall profits for his business.

loans.use: to purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Baba Sairam Self Help Group

texts.en:
Dukhi, 53, is married and has one daughter. Her family lives in a village of the Khorda district of Odisha, India. Dukhi and her husband earn a living through farming. They grow vegetables and rice in their field. Having been in this business for two years, she is able to earn approximately 5,000 INR per month to meet her family’s needs.
 
Dukhi is leading a group of 13 members to apply for a loan with People's Forum. As the leader, she is going to use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland and to cover operational costs. Other members of her group are engaged in different types of activities such as goat farming and operating general stores. With this loan, she hopes to grow more crops and sell them for a good price to make a better living to send her children to school. The members of the group Baba Sairam Self Help Group are very responsible and ambitious.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing fertilizers and pesticides and to cover operational costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is a single mother who lives in Lyakajjulu trading center. She is a widow and lives with her two children, ages 6 years and 2 months old. She started this business of selling cows in the market in order to help her pay fees for her child.

With the loan she has asked for, she wants to buy some more calves so that she can fatten them and sell them at a profit in the cattle market. She also has a bar from where she earns additional income.

loans.use: To buy some cows

loans.name: Favour Ii Group

texts.en:
Hawa is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Hawa is 33 years old, single, and has four children, two of whom attend school.  She was born in Gbense. Hawa has been a businesswoman for two years, selling sardines, sugar, sweets, milk, cigarettes, candles, books, pens, soaps, etc.  

With the help of this loan, Hawa and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales, and improve on their living conditions. Hawa will use her share of the loan (500,000 SLL) to buy sardines, sugar, sweets, milk, cigarettes, candles, books, pens, soaps, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to purchase sardines, sugar, sweets, milk, cigarettes, candles, books, pens, soaps, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Friend Sisters Group

texts.en:
Fanta is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fanta was born in Gbense-Kono, 43 years ago. She is married to a diamond miner and the couple has two children – one in primary school and one in secondary school.

 For three years now, Fanta has been selling cloth and clothes. This is the first loan that Fanta and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Fanta will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy cloth and clothes at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy cloth and clothes at wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Leh We Help Weself Group

texts.en:
Fanta is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fanta was born in Sandor, 56 years ago. She is married to a driver and the couple has four children who are attending primary and secondary school. Fanta sells slippers and flip-flops and has been doing business for seven years now. 

With the help of this loan, Fanta and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Fanta will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to buy slippers and flip-flops in large quantity to add to her current stock. 

(Also attached to the right of the photo is a borrower who was not present for the group snap shot.)

loans.use: to buy slippers and flip-flops in large quantity to add to her current stock

loans.name: New Life Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present the members of the 'New Life' group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person in the group to invest in their respective businesses. 

Jeneba is the featured leader of this group. Jeneba is 30, and married with three children – one in primary school, one in secondary school, and the other is too young for school. 

Jeneba sells palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, rice, sugar, flour, etc. and has been doing this business for three years. 

With the help of this loan, Jeneba will invest in her business by buying the above mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, rice, sugar, flour, etc.  in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for a zero grazing unit

loans.name: One Word Organisation Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “One Word Organisation” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 3,400,000 SLL for the entire group in order to expand their businesses.
 
The leader of this group is Aminata.  Aminata is a native of Segbema. She is married to a trader and the couple has three children – two in primary school and one in secondary school. Aminata has been a businesswoman for three years now. She sells palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). Aminata has requested this loan in order to buy gallons of palm oil to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Tamarneh Ii Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the 'Tamarneh II' group from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their respective businesses, increase their sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Aminata is the featured leader of this group. The 45 year old is married to a businessman. Aminata has been a businesswoman for seven years; she sells groundnuts/peanuts and soap.  

With her share of this loan, she is going to a buy a large quantity of groundnuts and soap to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to a buy a large quantity of groundnuts and soap to add to her current stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for a chuff cutter

loans.name: Super Unit Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Super Unit” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 800,000 SLL for each in order to expand their respective businesses. 

The leader of this group is Jariatu. She is 47 years old and a native of Lunsar. She is married to a trader and the couple has five children – two in primary school and three in secondary school. Jariatu has been a businesswoman for seven years now. She sells cultural beads, chains, earrings, combs, mirrors, etc. Jariatu has requested this loan in order to buy cultural beads, chains, earrings, combs, mirrors, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy cultural beads, chains, earrings, combs, mirrors, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, salt, pepper, sugar, flour, rice, etc. at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La clienta vive en Guayaquil. Empezó  vendiendo especies en el norte oeste de  la ciudad, luego se cambio al suburbio y a podido crecer su clientela a quienes le vende los especies como aji, ajo, ajinomoto, sal.

Su dificultad es cuando tiene recaídas producto de su enfermedad ya que ella es pvvs (personas viviendo con vih sida) y la delincuencia q hay en el sector donde tiene su negocio.

Es soltera, no tiene hijos. Con el préstamo quiere comprar especies. Su sueño es disfrutar a sus seres queridos y distribuir las especies a más personas , tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
This borrower lives in Guayaquil. She began selling spices in the northwestern part of the city. She later moved to the suburbs and was able to grow her clientele. The borrower sells spices such as aji chili peppers, garlic, MSG, and salt.

Her difficulty is whenever she has a relapse of her illness. The borrower is a person living with HIV/AIDS. She must also deal with the presence of crime in the area where she has her business.

The borrower is single and has no children. She will use this loan to buy spices. Her dreams include enjoying the company of her loved ones, selling spices to more people, and having a house of her own.

loans.use: to buy spices such as aji chili peppers, garlic, MSG, and salt.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cigarettes, milk, sugar, batteries, soap, toothpaste, biscuits, sweets, books, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Abu

texts.en:
Presented to you in the photo above is Abu, a machine operator at a sugar producing company in Sierra Leone. The 31-year-old machine operator is married to a businesswoman and the couple has four children, one of whom is attending primary school; the rest are still not of school-going age.

Abu has been working at the sugar company for six years now. With this loan, Abu is going to buy house-building materials like corrugated iron sheets, cement, nails, etc. for the construction of a dwelling house for his family.

loans.use: to buy house-building materials like corrugated  iron sheets, cement, nails, etc. for the construction of a dwelling house for his family

loans.name: Abiut

texts.en:
Abiut lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. He has three children, and has been doing this work for four years.  His primary income sources are eggs, crops, and salary from a job. He will use the loan to buy poultry birds.

He said that "poultry keeping!" is what is most enjoyable about farming. His biggest challenge is "poultry diseases and expensive poultry feeds".

Abiut was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, and he replied, "Because Juhudi  gives loans to farmers at favorable terms..".  This client was also asked what he learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, "There are loans given to farmers or small scale entrepreneurs".

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Abiut replied, "Income from the poultry project will help me educate my children".

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Abiut owns the following: poultry and bicycle, but does not own a cow, pig, pump, motorcycle, or automobile.  Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV, or a DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, increasing efficiency, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. He has four children and has been doing this work for 11 years.  His primary income sources are eggs, crops, and transportation services. He will use the loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Robert stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Dairy keeping and poultry keeping!' His biggest challenge is 'Animal diseases." One animal in the farm is named 'Maua.'

Robert was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Because Juhudi Kilimo gives loans to farmers to finance their activities.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'The various assets being financed by Juhudi Kilimo and the importance of directing funds to the intended projects.'

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Robert replied 'Income from the sale of milk will boost my other sources of income so as to educate my children and provide my family with other needs.'
